page.title: 15Yaxham Natural History
page.content: The dominance of arable farming on the landscape has tended to concentrate the 'natural' flora and fauna into the few small woods remaining and into gardens. A number of small ponds and wet meadows are rich in plant, insect and bird life but could not be classed as major wildlife habitats. Moles, Rats, and Rabbits are common. Foxes are seen occasionally. Bats are to be seen and have been recorded roosting in the church, in other buildings and in trees. Common bird species of the fields and hedgerows are Red-legged Partridge, Woodpigeon, Yellowhammer & Kestrel. Pheasants are common. Woodland species are less common, but Jay, Nuthatch and Lesser Spotted Woodpecker can be seen. In winter large numbers of Lapwing, Golden Plover, gulls and Starlings come to feed on the fields.
